questionText: A 34-year-old woman has fatigue and heavy menstrual bleeding. Labs: hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, MCV 70 fL, serum iron 18 µg/dL, ferritin 6 ng/mL, and total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) 480 µg/dL. Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
explanation:
Correct: Low ferritin and low serum iron with elevated TIBC indicates depleted iron stores, classic for iron deficiency anemia.

Why the other options are wrong: Anemia of chronic disease typically has low iron with low/normal TIBC and normal or high ferritin. Beta-thalassemia trait has microcytosis with normal or high iron stores and often an elevated RBC count. Sideroblastic anemia usually shows increased iron stores. Lead poisoning causes basophilic stippling and does not produce low ferritin with high TIBC.

questionText: A 58-year-old man with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis has hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL and MCV 78 fL. Iron studies show low serum iron, low transferrin, and ferritin 220 ng/mL. Which diagnosis best explains this pattern?
explanation:
Correct: Anemia of chronic disease (chronic inflammation) is characterized by low serum iron and low transferrin with normal or elevated ferritin due to iron sequestration.

Why the other options are wrong: Iron deficiency shows low ferritin and high TIBC/transferrin. Beta-thalassemia trait has microcytosis with normal or high iron stores. Vitamin B12 deficiency is macrocytic. Autoimmune hemolysis causes elevated reticulocytes and bilirubin, not low transferrin with high ferritin.

questionText: A 24-year-old woman of Mediterranean ancestry has mild fatigue. CBC shows hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL, MCV 67 fL, and an elevated RBC count. Iron studies are normal. Peripheral smear shows target cells. Which diagnosis is most likely?
explanation:
Correct: Beta-thalassemia trait causes microcytosis with normal iron studies and often an elevated RBC count; target cells support a hemoglobinopathy.

Why the other options are wrong: Iron deficiency has low ferritin and high TIBC. Anemia of chronic disease has low transferrin and normal/high ferritin. Aplastic anemia causes pancytopenia. Warm autoimmune hemolysis is typically normocytic with spherocytes and elevated reticulocytes.

questionText: A 32-year-old man presents with gingival bleeding and easy bruising. Labs show anemia, thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT and aPTT, and low fibrinogen. Peripheral smear shows abnormal promyelocytes. A representative histology image is provided below. What is the most appropriate initial therapy?
options: All-trans retinoic acid plus arsenic trioxide
correctAnswer: All-trans retinoic acid plus arsenic trioxide
explanation:
Correct: Acute promyelocytic leukemia is treated urgently with ATRA plus arsenic trioxide to induce differentiation and remission.

Why the other options are wrong: Standard AML induction (cytarabine/daunorubicin) is not first-line for APL. Imatinib targets BCR-ABL in CML. Rituximab targets CD20-positive B-cell malignancies. Observation is unsafe because APL often presents with life-threatening coagulopathy.

questionText: A 56-year-old man has early satiety and splenomegaly. CBC shows WBC 120,000/µL with left shift and basophilia. Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase is low. Which is the best initial therapy?
explanation:
Correct: This is chronic myeloid leukemia; first-line therapy targets BCR-ABL with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor such as imatinib.

Why the other options are wrong: ATRA treats APL. Rituximab is used for CD20-positive B-cell malignancies. Steroids or cyclophosphamide are not first-line for CML.

questionText: A 29-year-old woman has petechiae and epistaxis. Platelet count is 8,000/µL; hemoglobin and WBC count are normal. Peripheral smear shows normal platelet morphology and no schistocytes. Which is the most appropriate initial treatment?
explanation:
Correct: Immune thrombocytopenia is treated initially with corticosteroids (often with IVIG if bleeding is significant).

Why the other options are wrong: Platelet transfusion alone is ineffective without suppressing immune destruction. Splenectomy is reserved for refractory cases. Warfarin is contraindicated with severe thrombocytopenia. Observation is inappropriate with severe thrombocytopenia and mucosal bleeding.

questionText: A 67-year-old postoperative patient on unfractionated heparin develops a platelet drop from 240,000/µL to 90,000/µL on day 7 and a new femoral DVT. What is the best next step?
options: Give platelet transfusion and continue heparin
explanation:
Correct: Suspected HIT requires immediate discontinuation of heparin and initiation of a non-heparin anticoagulant such as argatroban.

Why the other options are wrong: Continuing heparin or switching to LMWH can worsen HIT. Platelet transfusion is not indicated unless there is life-threatening bleeding. Observation risks thrombosis progression.

questionText: A 20-year-old woman with sickle cell disease has fever, chest pain, cough, and a new pulmonary infiltrate. Oxygen saturation is 85% on room air despite supplemental oxygen. What is the best next step?
explanation:
Correct: Severe acute chest syndrome with hypoxemia warrants transfusion, often exchange transfusion, to rapidly reduce HbS and improve oxygen delivery.

Why the other options are wrong: Analgesia alone is insufficient. Phlebotomy worsens anemia. Steroids alone are not definitive. Observation risks rapid decompensation.

questionText: A 6-year-old boy has recurrent painful hemarthroses. Labs show prolonged aPTT with normal PT and platelet count. Which therapy is most appropriate for acute bleeding?
explanation:
Correct: Hemophilia A is due to factor VIII deficiency and is treated acutely with factor VIII replacement.

Why the other options are wrong: Factor IX replacement treats hemophilia B. Vitamin K does not correct congenital factor VIII deficiency. Aspirin and warfarin worsen bleeding.

questionText: A 64-year-old man with septic shock develops oozing from IV sites. Labs: platelets 40,000/µL, PT 22 sec, aPTT 58 sec, fibrinogen 90 mg/dL, and markedly elevated D-dimer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Correct: DIC presents with thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT/aPTT, low fibrinogen, and elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimer), often triggered by sepsis.

Why the other options are wrong: TTP usually has normal PT/aPTT and prominent neurologic/renal findings. ITP has isolated thrombocytopenia. Hemophilia A and vWD affect aPTT without severe thrombocytopenia and low fibrinogen.

questionText: A 66-year-old man has back pain, fatigue, and recurrent infections. Labs show anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated creatinine. Which diagnosis is most likely?
explanation:
Correct: Multiple myeloma commonly presents with bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal dysfunction (CRAB features).

Why the other options are wrong: Polycythemia vera causes elevated hemoglobin/hematocrit. CLL usually presents with lymphocytosis and lymphadenopathy. Aplastic anemia causes pancytopenia without hypercalcemia or bone pain. Hereditary spherocytosis causes hemolysis and splenomegaly.

questionText: A 67-year-old former smoker has COPD with CAT score 18 and mMRC 2. He has had no exacerbations in the past year. Which is the preferred initial maintenance therapy?
options: Short-acting beta agonist as needed only
Long-acting beta agonist plus long-acting muscarinic antagonist
Long-acting beta agonist plus inhaled corticosteroid
correctAnswer: Long-acting beta agonist plus long-acting muscarinic antagonist
explanation:
Correct: GOLD recommendations for symptomatic, low-exacerbation-risk patients (Group B) favor dual long-acting bronchodilator therapy (LABA/LAMA).

Why the other options are wrong: SABA-only is insufficient for persistent symptoms. LABA/ICS is not preferred initial therapy in COPD without asthma. Chronic systemic steroids and theophylline are not first-line.

questionText: A 19-year-old with asthma uses a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid daily but still has symptoms most days and wakes weekly with cough. FEV1 is 70% predicted. What is the best next controller step?
options: Add a long-acting beta agonist (ICS/LABA combination)
Stop ICS and use SABA only
Start a long-acting muscarinic antagonist alone
correctAnswer: Add a long-acting beta agonist (ICS/LABA combination)
explanation:
Correct: For persistent symptoms on low-dose ICS, step-up therapy includes adding a LABA (or using ICS-formoterol maintenance/reliever).

Why the other options are wrong: SABA-only therapy is not recommended for persistent asthma. Chronic oral steroids are reserved for severe refractory disease. Theophylline and LAMA alone are not preferred first step-up options.

questionText: A 23-year-old woman with asthma presents to the ED with severe wheezing. Peak expiratory flow is 45% predicted after initial albuterol. Which additional treatment reduces hospitalizations in moderate-to-severe exacerbations?
explanation:
Correct: Adding inhaled ipratropium to SABA therapy in moderate-to-severe asthma exacerbations reduces hospitalization risk.

Why the other options are wrong: Theophylline is not first-line for acute exacerbations. ICS alone is not sufficient in severe attacks. Antibiotics are not routine unless bacterial infection is suspected. Aspirin may worsen asthma in sensitive patients.

questionText: A 33-year-old woman has cough and dyspnea. Chest imaging shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy reveals noncaseating granulomas. She has limiting symptoms. What is the first-line therapy?
explanation:
Correct: Symptomatic sarcoidosis is treated first-line with systemic corticosteroids.

Why the other options are wrong: Bronchodilators do not treat granulomatous inflammation. Antibiotics are not indicated. TNF-alpha inhibitors are reserved for refractory disease. Observation alone is acceptable only in asymptomatic patients.

questionText: A 52-year-old man with obesity has loud snoring, witnessed apneas, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Polysomnography shows an apnea-hypopnea index of 32. What is the recommended first-line therapy?
options: Upper airway surgery as first line
explanation:
Correct: Positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP/APAP) is recommended as first-line treatment for obstructive sleep apnea.

Why the other options are wrong: Oral appliances are alternatives for those who prefer them or cannot tolerate CPAP. Surgery or oxygen alone is not first-line. Stimulants do not treat airway obstruction.

questionText: A 68-year-old man has progressive dyspnea and dry cough. HRCT shows basilar, subpleural honeycombing consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia. Which therapy slows disease progression?
explanation:
Correct: Antifibrotic therapy such as nintedanib is recommended to slow progression in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Why the other options are wrong: Bronchodilators and short-acting beta agonists do not modify fibrotic progression. Macrolides and prednisone alone are not standard disease-modifying therapy for IPF.

questionText: A 45-year-old woman has pleuritic chest pain and tachycardia. Wells score indicates intermediate probability. D-dimer is positive. She is hemodynamically stable. What is the next best diagnostic test?
options: No imaging; begin anticoagulation and reassess
explanation:
Correct: In low to intermediate probability patients with a positive D-dimer, CT pulmonary angiography is the recommended diagnostic test.

Why the other options are wrong: Doppler ultrasound may help but does not rule out PE. V/Q scan is an alternative when CTPA is contraindicated. Echocardiography is mainly for unstable patients. Empiric anticoagulation without imaging is not first-line in stable patients.

questionText: A 7-month-old infant has cough, wheezing, and rhinorrhea. RSV test is positive. SpO2 is 91% on room air and the child is feeding adequately. What is the best management?
options: Supportive care with hydration and supplemental oxygen only if needed
correctAnswer: Supportive care with hydration and supplemental oxygen only if needed
explanation:
Correct: Bronchiolitis management is primarily supportive with hydration and oxygen if saturation falls persistently below target thresholds.

Why the other options are wrong: Bronchodilators and steroids are not routinely recommended. Antibiotics are reserved for proven bacterial infection.

questionText: A 62-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history has a central cavitary lung mass on CT and chronic cough. Which lung cancer subtype is most likely?
explanation:
Correct: Squamous cell carcinoma is classically central/endobronchial and strongly associated with smoking, often with cavitation.

Why the other options are wrong: Adenocarcinoma is usually peripheral. Small cell is typically perihilar but is neuroendocrine and not classically cavitary. Large cell is often peripheral. Typical carcinoid is less associated with heavy smoking.
